msg: Mac And Cheese: Quick and Easy

rawMsg: If you are anything like me, you really appreciate a good mac and cheese. I used to make it with a roux-based sauce, which was decent, but not great. It had decent texture, but the flavor was lacking and I always wanted to have something else to serve alongside it. Enter [[ab]]. This one's a game-changer, folks. It's so good, and so easy that I've enshrined the recipe on a post-it right in the middle of my kitchen cabinets, where it'll stay until I've commited it to memory thanks to rote repitition.

alt: The post-it note I wrote for this recipe, text reproduced below

rawMsg: Return noodles to their pot, and melt butter into them over low heat. In a measuring cup, mix milk/eggs/salt/mustard together. Pour mixture over butter-coated noodles, and stir together. Gradually add cheese and stir over low heat until it's all melted, ~3 minutes. Portion into bowls and top with pepper as desired. Makes 3-4 servings as a side, or 2 as a standalone meal.

alt: 2 finished bowls of mac and cheese, ready to eat

rawMsg: The base recipe above is all you need if you're comfortable in the kitchen and have made this before, but in case you haven't you may be interested in following along with the dinner I made last night. The first thing you probably noticed is that I served my noodles with broccoli - I tend to enjoy adding some sort of green vegetable to the dish, as it then becomes a first-class meal for Amanda and I to share. Broccoli is particular is nice because it's very easy to "lightly cook", which I'll expand on below.

alt: All my ingredients gathed on the countertop

rawMsg: There's a lot going on here. I'm going to walk down the ingredient list and expand on each item so you know what your options are.

items: Pasta: Large elbows are my abosolute favorite in this dish, but you can use anything that looks like it'll hold sauce well. Here I'm using rotini, you could also sub in shells, wheels, or anything else they sell in your pasta aisle. Measure out half of a one pound box, and cook it according to package directions. If there's a range of times, use the smallest end of the range.

Cheese: Don't skimp here. As-sharp-as-possible cheddar is the default, this time we got ourselves a smoked variety. Since cheese usually comes in 8 ounce blocks but the recipe calls for 10, I supplement with whatever is laying around (such as goat cheese). Whatever you do, avoid pre-shredded bags if at all possible. The anti-coagulants they add will make for a rough time when you're trying to melt it all down into a smooth sauce.

Broccoli: If you're using peas or some other frozen veggie, cook them separately while the noodles are boiling and add them at the very end. For broccoli (and I'd assume several other types of fresh veggie), get them cut up and into the colander you're going to use to drain the pasta before the pasta finished cooking.

Evaporated Milk: This, as I understand it, is the secret to the quickness of this stovetop recipe. It tends to be sold in 12 ounce cans, so reserve the other half to go with your other half-box of pasta later in the week.

Butter/Eggs/Salt/Mustard/Pepper: Nothing special here, just add the ingredients as described in the base recipe. You can modify the spices a bit if desired; chili powder and smoked paprika have both hung out with ground mustard in my pot successfully before.

rawMsg: Start by boiling some water in your mac and cheese pot. Pick a large one, as it's going to hold the entire dish.

alt: My dutch oven on the stove, filled with water for pasta

rawMsg: While I waited for that, I started chopping up the broccoli. Remember, it goes into the colander!

alt: Partially chopped head of broccoli on my cutting board, next to the colander holding bite size florets

rawMsg: Once the water is at a rolling boil, add pasta. Give this a stir every so often to prevent starch-sticking to the bottom of the pot.

alt: The same dutch oven from before, now with pasta added in

rawMsg: As the pasta cooked, I finished the broccoli and moved on to shredding the cheese.

alt: A pile of freshly-shredded cheese on my cutting board

rawMsg: Now for the fun bit. Once the pasta is done, I drain it in the sink using my broccoli-filled colander. The heat of the pasta water will start cooking the broccoli, but there's no chance at all of having an overcooked mush.

alt: Action shot of pasta draining over broccoli
Another action shot of pasta draining over broccoli

rawMsg: Noodles and veggies both go back into the pot, where they're introduced to my good friend butter. While the butter melts, mix the milk, eggs, and spices in a measuring cup if you haven't already done so.

alt: Pasta, broccoli, and butter in the pot together

rawMsg: Once the butter is all melted, give the pot a good stir so that everything has a nice coating. Then pour in the milk mixture and give it a stir too.

alt: Action shot of milk mixture being poured into pot

rawMsg: Here comes the moneymaker. Gradually add the cheese, stirring as you go, and continue to stir over low heat until smooth.

alt: Cheese being added to the pot
More cheese being added to the pot

rawMsg: You'll know it's done when you hear that signature squelch of smooth creamy goodness. Serve and eat pronto, if it cools down the texture will get all weird. If that does happen (or you somehow have leftovers?), just reheat slowly until it looks irresistible again.

alt: A finished pot of mac and cheese

msg: Now go forth and be cheesy
